guild.description:
"For God so loved the world, that He gave His only begotten Son, that whoever believes in Him shall not perish, but have eternal life. This is the judgment, that the Light has come into the world, and men loved the darkness rather than the Light, for their deeds were evil. For everyone who does evil hates the Light, and does not come to the Light for fear that his deeds will be exposed. But he who practices the truth comes to the Light, so that his deeds may be manifested as having been wrought in God."

May all personally encounter the presence and attention of the Lord God. 

Curiosity, questions, discussion, and prayer requests are welcome.

body:
I know it's a slippery slope, but such is life. You have some fair concerns, but they aren't fixed by simply shutting down discourse. Generally, open discourse is better than shutting it down.

The decision of Christians to leave slavery in Babylon and Egypt and strike out into the wilderness was a *political* decision. The decision for Harad to remove the head of John the Baptist was a *political* decision. The decision of Pilate to crucify Jesus was a *political* decision. In reality, you can't separate these concepts into two separate bins. It can be harmful to do so. 

We should not separate our life into Church and secular. It is one life. Our Christian lessons are meant for the marketplace.

body:
I hear ya. Certainly seems that way, eh? I think this comes down to a question of how you're defining the words. 

You're using 'politics' to mean the normal status quo of the word. While I'm using the word's actual definition, independent of the way it's largely being misused currently. It's important for us to get back to the actual definition of the word, though, so let's not throw it away.

Ultimately, politics is and should be a question of living principals.
